prior_works.title: 3D Gaussian Splatting for Real-Time Radiance Field Rendering
prior_works.authors: Bernhard Kerbl, Georgios Kopanas, Thomas Leimkühler, George Drettakis
prior_works.relationship_sentence: EGGS builds directly on 3DGS’s anisotropic 3D Gaussian primitives and GPU rasterization pipeline, addressing 3DGS’s multi-view inconsistency by introducing a complementary 2D counterpart and mechanisms to switch between them.

prior_works.title: Surface Splatting
prior_works.authors: Mario Zwicker, Hanspeter Pfister, Jeroen van Baar, Markus Gross
prior_works.role: Classical 2D Gaussian splatting in screen space
prior_works.relationship_sentence: EGGS’s 2D Gaussian component inherits the idea of image-space elliptical (Gaussian) splats from Surface Splatting, leveraging their multi-view consistency and anti-aliasing properties within a modern, differentiable, unified rasterizer.

prior_works.title: NeRF: Representing Scenes as Neural Radiance Fields for View Synthesis
prior_works.authors: Ben Mildenhall, Pratul P. Srinivasan, Matthew Tancik, Jonathan T. Barron, Ravi Ramamoorthi, Ren Ng
prior_works.role: Volumetric rendering and multi-view supervision paradigm
prior_works.relationship_sentence: EGGS follows NeRF’s multi-view photometric supervision framework and geometry–appearance trade-off insights, but replaces implicit fields with explicit Gaussian primitives that can be 2D or 3D and are adaptively exchanged.

prior_works.title: Mip-NeRF: A Multiscale Representation for Anti-Aliasing Neural Radiance Fields
prior_works.authors: Jonathan T. Barron, Ben Mildenhall, Matthew Tancik, Peter Hedman, Ricardo Martin-Brualla, Pratul P. Srinivasan
prior_works.relationship_sentence: EGGS’s Frequency-Decoupled Optimization echoes Mip-NeRF’s anti-aliasing and frequency-aware training principles, using frequency separation to exploit the strengths of 2D vs. 3D Gaussians for geometry vs. appearance.

prior_works.title: PlenOctrees for Real-time Rendering of Neural Radiance Fields
prior_works.authors: Alex Yu, Ruilong Li, Matthew Tancik, Hao Li, Ren Ng, Angjoo Kanazawa
prior_works.role: Explicit, GPU-efficient NVS with custom rendering
prior_works.relationship_sentence: EGGS adopts the philosophy of explicit, GPU-amenable scene representations and custom CUDA rendering from PlenOctrees, adapting these ideas to a unified hybrid Gaussian rasterizer for fast training/inference.

prior_works.title: QSplat: A Multiresolution Point Rendering System for Large Meshes
prior_works.relationship_sentence: EGGS’s hybrid rasterization and adaptive type exchange are conceptually aligned with point-based rendering’s use of splats and level-of-detail, extending these ideas to switchable 2D/3D Gaussian primitives optimized per-view and per-frequency.

synthesis_narrative:
EGGS sits at the intersection of explicit Gaussian primitives, point-based rendering, and frequency-aware neural view synthesis. Its 3D side squarely builds on 3D Gaussian Splatting (Kerbl et al.), inheriting anisotropic 3D Gaussians, alpha compositing, and a GPU-first rasterization pipeline that delivers real-time appearance fidelity. To counter 3DGS’s multi-view inconsistencies, EGGS revives and modernizes the core idea of screen-space Gaussian splats from Surface Splatting, introducing a 2D Gaussian pathway that naturally enforces cross-view consistency and anti-aliased accumulation.
NeRF provides the multi-view supervision paradigm and the lens through which geometry–appearance trade-offs are framed, while Mip-NeRF’s multiscale anti-aliasing informs EGGS’s Frequency-Decoupled Optimization: separating low- vs. high-frequency signals so 2D Gaussians can stabilize geometry and 3D Gaussians can capture fine appearance. From PlenOctrees, EGGS takes the ethos of explicit, CUDA-optimized rendering for training and inference efficiency, but applies it to a unified rasterizer capable of handling both 2D and 3D splats. Finally, classic point-based systems like QSplat inform EGGS’s adaptive mechanism—analogous to LOD selection—by enabling dynamic exchange between 2D and 3D Gaussian types based on scene content and optimization signals.
Together, these works directly shape EGGS’s three core ingredients: a unified hybrid rasterizer, an adaptive type-exchange policy balancing geometry and appearance, and a frequency-decoupled training strategy that exploits the complementary strengths of 2D and 3D Gaussian representations.
